item.title: Corona Geek #188 – Reducing collision calculations with quadtrees and Spine runtime mesh support
item.dc:creator: Charles McKeever
item.description: On this week's Corona Geek podcast, René Aye from Devil Squid showed the panel how to reduce the number of collision calculations using Quadtrees. We talked about Corona's new support for meshes, Steven Johnson showed off some of his mesh related plugin work, and Vlad Shcherban shared a Core Engineer's perspective on adding mesh support.
item.content:encoded:
On this week’s Corona Geek podcast, René Aye from Devil Squid showed the panel how to reduce the number of collision calculations using Quadtrees. We also talked about Corona’s new support for meshes. Steven Johnson showed off some of his mesh related plugin work and Vlad Shcherban shared a Core Engineer’s perspective on adding mesh support. Download the updated Spine runtime to get all the mesh support goodness.

Show notes:

  • DevilSquid Quadtree example code

Panelists:

  • René Aye
  • Ed Maurina
  • Steven Johnson
  • Sergey Lerg
  • Mike Hempfling
  • Jason Schroeder
  • Vlad Shcherban
  • Rob Miracle
  • Charles McKeever

Promote Your Apps:

  • Add your app to the Corona Showcase
  • Submit your app to be a Case Study candidate

Thank you for watching, listening, and following Corona Geek:

  • Subscribe to Corona Geek on YouTube
  • Download Corona Geek on iTunes
  • Follow Corona Geek on Facebook

item.title: Corona Geek #187 – Using LDoc to create amazing app project documentation
item.dc:creator: Charles McKeever
item.description: On today's Corona Geek podcast, René Aye from Devil Squid introduced us to creating project documentation using LDoc. He also gave us pointers on how to format Lua table parameters using markdown. The panel also discussed the merits of using different monetization options in apps and shared ideas on how to improve the experience for the user and increase value for both advertisers and the app developers.
item.content:encoded:
On this week’s Corona Geek podcast, René Aye from Devil Squid introduced the panel to creating project documentation using LDoc. René generates documentation for his Neon Shapes Github repo using a combination of LDoc and markdown. He also gave us pointers on how to format Lua table parameters using markdown.

The panel also discussed the merits of using different monetization options in apps and also shared ideas on how to improve the user experience for the user and increase value for both the advertiser and the app developer.

Show notes:

  • Installing LDoc
  • Combining LDoc and Markdown
  • Example of HTML files hosted on BitBucket, with docs rendered via Github
  • Neonshapes with Corona SDK
  • Android Instant Apps for Developers At Google I/O 2016
  • Google Play Early Access
  • MediaBrix branded ad products

Panelists:

  • René Aye
  • Ed Maurina
  • Steven Johnson
  • Sergey Lerg
  • Mike Hempfling
  • Tony Godfrey
  • Jason Schroeder
  • Terry Schussler
  • Charles McKeever

Promote Your Apps:

  • Add your app to the Corona Showcase
  • Submit your app to be a Case Study candidate

Thank you for watching, listening, and following Corona Geek:

  • Subscribe to Corona Geek on YouTube
  • Download Corona Geek on iTunes
  • Follow Corona Geek on Facebook

item.title: From the Forum — Issue #108
item.dc:creator: Rob Miracle
item.description: Welcome to the latest installment of From the Forum. In this series, guest blogger Alex Jackson highlights outstanding threads from the Corona Forum. The goal is to bring attention to the most captivating, interesting, and thought-provoking discussions taking place in our very own backyard.
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the latest installment of From the Forum. In this series, guest blogger Alex Jackson highlights outstanding threads from the Corona/ Forum. The goal is to bring attention to the most captivating, interesting, and thought-provoking discussions taking place in our very own backyard.

Please visit/ the forum to join these conversations or start your own!

Parse leaves a void

For those of us who have been living under a rock may be surprised to learn that Parse, one of the most powerful third party server backends, has announced plans to shutter its service in a year’s time. There are a fair amount of Corona apps created with a Parse backbone, so this is potentially a huge blow to the community.

Where do we go from here? There are several different options in the realm of backends server products. You can’t shake a stick without hitting one. However, today we’re going to highlight a solution that combines a few different pieces into a virtual Voltron of awesomeness.

Corona dev (and our new best friend) Simon Fearby details how to get a managed server solution implemented that replaced Parse in functionality, with step by step instructions. Do yourself a favor and check out the link, and don’t forget to say thanks!

https://forums.coronalabs.com/topic/61378-parse-is-dying-now-what/

Documentation: the elephant in the room

I love backstory. I usually err on the side of over-explaining, sometimes, to my detriment. When it comes to documentation, though, I drop the ball and just start creating syntax that is nigh-impossible to decipher.

If you’re like me, there is how fire us after all. Instead of resorting to electric shock, we can leverage a handy program called Ldoc. Developer Rene from DevilSquid lays out the details on its use, and even gives some instructions and pointers for getting started.

Check out the original thread to see where Ldoc can fit into your workflow. Documentation for a program that generated documentation? What a time to be alive.

https://forums.coronalabs.com/topic/61391-how-to-document-lua-code-with-ldoc/

A fill, three years in the making

Way back during the pre-Graphics 2.0 days, we imagined new ways to use our compositions and captured images in interesting ways. With the advent of snapshots, many though a fill using the same was just around the corner.

At last, Vlad from Corona has delivered the coolest of fills, allowing us to finally use snapshots. It’s a new feature, and one that needs the tired kicked on it by the entire Corona community. So do Vlad and yourself a favor, check out the original thread, and see how you can start using snapshot fills in your apps and games right now!

https://forums.coronalabs.com/topic/40590-snapshot-as-paint-input/

About Alex

Alex Jackson is an indie developer and the founder of Panc Interactive, specializing in retro-style gaming. He has created several mobile applications, enjoys long walks on the beach, pixel art, and reading the Corona forums. Contact him by email or follow him on Twitter: @pancinteractive. Check out his new game Segreta on iOS, Android, Windows Phone and Amazon devices.
